Displaced workers tend to be not only older, but less educated and have held the lost job for longer than workers generally.
The Commission's concern and its determination to rebalance this unequal redistribution is because, in political—as well as social and economic—terms,
"this mismatch directly fuels rejection of the opening up of the economy".

In other words, it leads to protectionism. It is a timely and accurate analysis requiring active programmes to respond to these "market externalities" of globalisation, and I think we would all accept their emphasis on dealing with information gaps, through job search assistance, for example; qualification gaps, through tailor-made training; and geographical mismatch, through relocation allowances, and so on. I think everyone would acknowledge the broader point that, as we move relentlessly to employment in service sectors, with ipso facto different earnings distribution from manufacturing, the sectoral shift per se brings with it a negative impact on the overall distribution of income.

However, it is an impact which a number of other European countries have, unlike Britain, been able to neutralise. The big picture, if I may oversimplify, is the Anglo-Saxon countries versus the rest; pure capitalism, if you like, versus the social market variety of most of the European Union. Samuel Brittan—not a left-wing firebrand—in an essay in the Financial Times on 10 February on the American experience of extravagant top salaries, and an explanation of the distributional effects of globalisation, says that the pay of chief executive officers rose by 100 per cent in the past decade, while that for maths and computer sciences occupations rose by less than 5 per cent. He questions the reliance, as in the report of the House of Lords Economic Affairs Committee, on the "shift of skills and technology" explanation of these effects. He concludes:
"One day, competition from China and India will deal with bloated top salaries. But not yet".

Here in Britain, too, it is the chief executives and other executive directors of top companies—particularly of global corporations—who are prominent among the winners in this game of snakes and ladders. When I say "Britain", I had better include the Isle of Man, with no corporate tax, and the Channel Islands and the Cayman Islands—companies with household names are registered in all three. The UK is a prominent home for multinational corporations, which make up one-third of world output and two-thirds of world trade, half of which takes place within the transnationals themselves, at prices which they often fix in order to minimise tax.

But company law and tax law at national level have themselves been so far overtaken by globalisation that, in the vast proportion of cases, boards feel they are under no pressure to discuss the rationale of directors' remuneration. Remuneration committees do not so far include workers representatives—an overdue reform some of us have been campaigning for—and the picture is generally as Samuel Brittan describes it for the US, even if the numbers here are not quite so extravagant.

To avoid any misunderstanding about where I am coming from, I very much welcome the fact that India and China are growing at 10 per cent per annum. There is no way in which typical European countries which are 10 times better off need to flagellate themselves about not growing at that pace. That is what world development is all about. The need for the trade unions to work together within sectors and multinationals was the theme of a lecture I gave a couple of years ago in Bangalore to professionals as well as trade unions. The last thing we want is any doctrine that the interests of workers in Britain and in India, for example, are opposed.

But we have a difficulty. With globalisation now taking centre stage as a catch-all explanation for almost everything that moves—mergers and acquisitions also spring to mind—the perception which our members are taking from the debate is that, in a number of sectors, they are becoming more vulnerable and that, in this brave new world, any idea of having an overall policy on income distribution is now as viable as King Canute trying to stop the incoming tide. That is the perception—what people think they are being told—which my noble friend now has an opportunity to correct.
Of course, the media have fallen for this new historicism hook, line and sinker. Even the Financial Times, normally cool and analytical, opined on 7 February that shorter working time was now,
"unsustainable in the face of competition from China and India".

It was, paradoxically, only a few days later that it ran a story highlighting the growing dilemmas of work/life balance in this country—notably, but not exclusively, for women—arising from our long hours culture.

The share of the top 1 per cent of income recipients in Britain has in recent years jumped back to pre-war levels. The richest 1 per cent doubled their share of pre-tax income from 6.7 per cent in 1981 to 13 per cent in 1999—precisely the same as in 1937, the year of my birth, so we have gone back 68 years. This top 1 per cent last year paid themselves some £100 billion pre-tax, and about £75 billion post-tax. As the American Senator would have said, "£100 billion here and £100 billion there soon starts to add up to real money".

For those of you who cannot quite get the hang of billions, a topical comparison—I say this with my tongue firmly in my cheek—is that £100 billion corresponds to the proceeds of 2,000 top-of-the-range bank robberies. And for anyone who thinks that there is something tricky about quoting the top 1 per cent, the share of the top 10 per cent in the UK also rose from 28 per cent in 1979 to 40 per cent before tax in 1999—that is £350 billion—and from 26 per cent in 1979 to 36 per cent in 1999 after tax—that is £270 billion. That trend has certainly not been reversed, if one reads company reports.

Britain is unique in the EU in this huge growth of differentials at the top. In an important study comparing Britain with the Netherlands—an economy with a similar degrees of openness to that of the United Kingdom—Professor Tony Atkinson, with his unchallenged reputation in this field, found that their top 10 per cent shares were absolutely unchanged between 1979 and 1999, at 28 per cent before tax and 24 per cent after tax; in other words, a huge way below ours. Indeed, Britain now finds itself with Spain, Greece and Portugal in a distinct group at the end of the European inequality league table, with the Nordics being at the other end. Incidentally, the latter are collectively the winners of the world competitiveness index. To those who say that this explosion of top incomes is the specific result of innovation and generally brilliant performance, the only answer in Lancastrian is, "Pull the other one!". Do the Dutch, Swedes and Finns not innovate as well?

I am looking forward to this short debate. I saw reports that David Cameron was making a speech about a one nation approach to social and economic progress under the banner "Young Etonians for Social Justice and Equality of Opportunity in a Globalised World". Perhaps the noble Lord, Lord Howard of Rising, who I welcome onto the Front Bench for this debate, will be able to give us more details.

My Lords, I am sure that I speak for a number of noble Lords when I say that although we may not be a very full Chamber, the importance of this topic is none the less much greater than the attendance would suggest. We are dealing with a phenomenon that will decide not only our future, but that of our children and grandchildren. We are dealing with a phenomenon which, as the noble Lord, Lord Lea of Crondall, has so eloquently said, is constantly being described in terms that make it sound like the tide coming in—something that we can do absolutely nothing about.

I remember a family friend's child—brought up in a strictly urban setting—was given a set of tide tables for a part of the Isle of Wight, where we were, and said "I don't expect they keep to them", imagining that, like buses, they were subject to human control. Globalisation has to be. We are not experiencing something totally new. After all, there have always been superpowers with global ambitions—and we as a nation have been particularly prominent in that field.

Globalisation is not something to be either afraid of or surprised about. What has changed, I venture to suggest, is that technology and the explosion in the world money supply has meant that money itself has far more power in the human economy than it has ever had before. Possessions were previously measured much more in terms of static objects such as houses and estates. Now they have numbers and they move very fast. Since the oil price rises of the 1970s and since the explosion of plastic and other computerised technology for the manipulation of money we now find money much more determinative of people's attitudes and much more prominent in their ambitions. People have always wanted to be wealthy, but the fact of the power of money makes a huge difference to how wealth is conceived and how wealth is manipulated. That is exactly what gives rise to the phenomenon to which the noble Lord has drawn such eloquent attention.

When the Doctrine Commission of the Church of England produced a report called Being Human, a report on the character of human being in our time, it thought it necessary, as well as having obvious chapters on things like sex and power, to have one on money. It did that not because it did not realise that what the Scriptures talk about is the love of money, but because it recognised that money had come to the point where it generates its own speed and its own love of itself. That is why we are at a time when it is crucially important that humankind takes control of this phenomenon. It is a world that is of course getting smaller; a world in which movement is faster; and a world in which we have the possibility of becoming more aware of one another and our effect on one another. But that makes it crucially important that we do not surrender to the view that this is like some global tide. It is actually within the realms of possibility that human beings should control their future and should take to themselves the advantages and possibilities of an increasingly global way of living. That means of course attending to the effects of what produces prosperity for some on the poverty and vulnerability of some of those most deeply affected in our own country and of course elsewhere.

So, we need to overcome the polarisation which has existed between those who favour regulation, which is thought to be left wing, and those who do not, which is thought to be right wing. We need to discover ways of guiding—not perhaps regulating but guiding—that development, which is so crucial to us all. We need to find ways of capturing for humankind the values and the possibilities of humankind, the globalisation process. We are not here to stop it. We are not here to moan about it. We are here to humanise it and to make it our own, for the sake of ourselves and our children.

My Lords, this is an important debate and I thank my noble friend Lord Lea for raising the issue. Tacking poverty and inequality can only come from economic growth. Often when I hear people in Britain or Europe talking about globalisation I think they are missing the point. After all, what we call globalisation has generated huge economic benefits for Britain. Let us face it; some parts of Britain would be like the Sahara desert without the huge investments from the Japanese, the Germans or the Americans. Did they come to the UK and to Europe for lower labour costs? Of course they did not. They came to Britain for access to the market. In the process they have created large numbers of high-value jobs.

We cannot pick and choose when it comes to globalisation. This is the new world in which we are living. Our best companies are doing well because of globalisation. Whether that is Tesco exploiting a global supply chain, Vodafone exploiting global markets, BP harvesting global resources or RBS making global investments. They are all succeeding in a global environment.

The big issue today is the developments in Asia. Ten or 15 years ago the issue was the out-sourcing of some manufacturing from the US to the Pacific Rim countries. The debate was often expressed in terms of labour costs. The "tiger economies" are relatively small and with export-led growth, labour costs played a minor part, particularly in sectors such as electronics. But the current situation is different. And labour costs are not the be all and end all when it comes to decisions about where to locate production. The consequences today are of the opening up of China and India. They are not small "tigers"; they have markets that dwarf anything we have ever seen before.

For manufacturers the motive for investment is not just about off-shoring production but about the desire to be a part of these new, fast-growing markets. Countries such as China and India say that if you want to sell it in our country you have to come and make it here. That is what their governments and their people want. For market access they require us to manufacture in their markets, generating jobs and purchasing power and a positive spiral of economic development; and why not? Is that not what we have been doing in Europe for many years? The route to success in this new environment has to be one based on partnership. Over the coming years we can expect, at best, sluggish economic growth. We have all got to pursue higher growth in these emerging markets. In other words, the only way to get good economic growth in Britain will be by riding on the back of the Chinese and the Indians.

The world's economic centre of gravity has moved east. Sometimes I think our leaders in politics and industry are in denial about this simple fact. The old colonial days of trade following the flag have long gone. Access to these markets cannot always be by the simple route of exporting. There is no single way of entering these new markets. The key word is partnership. Establishing production facilities and distribution networks in a new market can be very time-consuming and costly. Firms will need to pursue alternative strategies ranging from mergers and acquisitions, to alliances and joint ventures if they are to gain access to these new markets.

As I have said, the key word is partnership. This requires a far better understanding of these nations and markets than we have shown so far. After all, our export performance to China and India has not been particularly outstanding. Our competitors often out-perform us. We hear a lot about Chinese exports, but it is an importer too. Between 1999 and 2004 US exports to China went up by 159 per cent. From the EU countries we trail well behind Germany, France and Italy. Our export business with China is less than one-sixth that of Germany. Recently, one of the leaders of the UK business community commented that Germany was in a difficult position because it had not restructured its manufacturing economy. Would that be the Germany that in a joint venture, Shanghai-Volkswagen, now has one-third of the Chinese auto market, selling some 700,000 units in 2004?

With India we start in a stronger position. Between 1996 and 2004 our exports grew at 3 per cent per annum—not bad, until one realises that that is less than half the growth of the Indian economy. That is leading to the erosion of our market share. It is not just in cricket that we have to raise our game in Asia. Our response to the new Asia has often been neo-colonialist in character. We hear talk of a knowledge-based economy in which there is somehow a global division of labour, a division that means that we do all the clever stuff—the design, research and development—while all the manufacturing is done elsewhere. There are two flaws to that argument. First, what is to stop the Indians or the Chinese from doing the higher added-value work? Last year, China produced 21 per cent of the world's software graduate engineers against 7 per cent for India and 5 per cent in the United States.

A couple of weeks ago I was addressing the Indian Institute of Technology at Kharagpur, which is my alma mater. I first went there 50 years ago. Today it is ranked in third place in the global league for technology universities. Tell its students that they can only do the manual work! Furthermore, what makes us think that we can do without a vibrant manufacturing sector? Manufacturing is still a major source of wealth creation and we have to make sure that we are up there with Sweden and Denmark spending money on research and development and innovation. At the same time, we must attract the best people to come to this country and therefore we must make sure that the way in which they access our competitive markets for work is simplified. The Chancellor of the Exchequer must also make sure that the regulatory and fiscal environment in this country is good for every year for indirect investment.

Therefore, in tabling the Question my noble friend was articulate in expressing his concern for the rise of inequality here in Britain: a concern I wholeheartedly share. As I have already said, the surest way to tackle poverty and inequality is from economic growth. If the UK is to continue to grow in the global environment we will have to leverage to some extent the economic growth in Asia to maintain growth here in the UK. That is the only way that we will be able to maintain downward pressure on inequality and poverty. Failure to do so can lead only to a rise in unemployment and inequality here in Britain.

My Lords, let me too thank my noble friend Lord Lea for initiating the debate. It is always good to be in discussion with a fellow stalwart of the House of Lords tennis team as it goes on its all-conquering way.

I first started studying globalisation intensively in the 1980s. That was about the same time that I left the academia bit and moved into a more political environment. At that time I could not get any political leader, politician or anyone else much to be interested in globalisation. Now the position has reversed: we cannot stop politicians or other people from talking about it. The result is that globalisation is often blamed for things that are not the result of globalisation, and other things are attributed to it that come from different sources. I am going to concentrate on the distribution of wealth in the UK. It is possible that globalisation has some impact on the distribution of wealth, but many other factors do as well, so it is a mistake simply to concentrate on globalisation if one talks about the distribution of wealth and what one should do about it.

What do we know about the distribution of wealth? We know, first, that this country is highly unequal. One per cent of the population owns about 32 per cent of total wealth. About 50 per cent of the population owns about 90 per cent of total wealth. We know that shareholding is even more unequal than wealth in general. Secondly, we know that the situation is worsening; that is, the distribution of wealth seems to be becoming more unequal in this country than it used to be. That is not the same as the distribution of income, incidentally, because the latest data on the distribution of income, measured usually by economists by the genie coefficient, show that the distribution of income has stabilised. Most people attribute that to government policy: for many years since the late 1970s it was increasing, but it has now stabilised.

Thirdly, there is a possible connection between the increasing inequality of wealth and globalisation. It might be found in the so-called "winner take all" effect; that is, as corporations become larger, as they become global corporations, who leads them becomes more important; therefore those who lead them receive higher remuneration because there is more competition on a global level. That is much the same thing, one might say, as has happened in professional football, if you follow the events of the past 20 years or so since the setting up of the Premier League, where salaries have increased staggeringly. That is income, rather than wealth, of course.

Does it matter what the top 1 per cent earn and what they do with their wealth, or their income? The new Labour approach so far has been to say that it does not matter too much. New Labour has concentrated on alleviating the position of the poor; it has raised about 2 million poorer people out of poverty—a notable achievement. There is some sense in that, because there are far more poor people than rich people. Whatever you do to the top 1 per cent in terms of redistribution will not matter very much. Does it matter about the top 1 per cent? I think: "Yes, you bet it does". The Government must take seriously overall inequality, not just the position of the poor. Therefore, we should ask what we can do to reduce the inequality of wealth that we have in this country.

There are two or three things that one could consider. First, it would be a mistake to raise top levels of income tax. In fact, the top 1 per cent of income earners pay a greater proportion of tax these days than they did 30 years ago, when the top tax rates were much higher. Secondly, we can consider inheritance tax. A study by the Institute for Public Policy Research about a year ago suggested a more progressive inheritance tax. That is a sensible move and a sensible framework for it was suggested in that study.

Thirdly, we can develop a more philanthropic culture in this country. It is not only the poor who should be good citizens; it is not only the poor should be told that rights carry obligations. Richer people should be told and should follow the same injunction. The wealthy in this country give away a far smaller proportion of their income and assets to charities than they do in the United States. You could argue that the UK gets the worst of both worlds, because it does not have high tax rates at the top but people do not give away much of their wealth. In the US, they give away enormous amounts—more than would be attributable to high tax rates in continental countries; so it is a kind of voluntary tax. We are not very successful in that at the moment here.

Fourthly, we could consider what happens in corporations, because corporate salaries are not necessarily the result of "winner takes all" competition; they could simply be the result of power. We know that there is not a close connection between the success of corporations and the money that the executives in those corporations get. We also know that the leaders of corporations do not bear the risk that they expect their employees to bear, because they are normally protected by pension systems when they take on a job.

In conclusion, I have two questions for the Minister. Does my noble friend agree that we should be doing more at the top and that we should not just concentrate on poverty but that we should take seriously overall inequality, especially inequality of wealth, and strive if we can to reverse the trend of the past 20 years? Secondly, does he think that it is worth while following initiatives that Patricia Hewitt made when she was head of the DTI, when she set up schemes—or tried to—that would more closely connected the salaries of top executives with the performances of the companies that they run?

My Lords, my noble friend Lord Lea has raised a very important Question, for which I am very grateful. I shall concentrate my few minutes on answering that Question. As my noble friend Lord Giddens said, inequalities have not worsened due to globalisation. If we really care about incomes, maybe we should care about median income or incomes in lower deciles.

However, we are talking about wealth inequalities and the question is: why have wealth inequalities grown more in the UK than in comparable developed European economies? I have a brief answer to that, which takes off from what the right reverend Prelate the Bishop of Worcester said. That is that it is a well known phenomenon that when income expands by a factor of X, trade expands by a multiple of X.

Finance has expanded by a much larger proportion of income since globalisation—deregulated capital markets—happened. For example, there are many more stock markets across the world than there were before. In stock markets, there are many more assets, especially in hedge funds, and so on. So financial markets have grown. It is almost like a reverse pyramid effect: from a small base of income there is a large fanning out of financial markets.

Therefore, those people who have access to the kind of skills that are financial-market related can make enormous incomes or losses. In the UK, for example, given the way in which our housing market is biased, people invest much less in equities than in houses so that, by the time you come to invest in equities, you must be very rich. Therefore, the benefits of financial market expansion accrue to those who take part in equity markets. The returns for people with skills in the financial markets in terms of their salaries and share options are a multiple of what anyone else can get in manufacturing or even in hi-tech services. There is a Chinese fan effect: because the UK has one of the most successful financial centres in the world, many financial services and corporations are concentrated here, and many multinational corporations prefer to have their headquarters here. So very large incomes that accrue global returns, as my noble friend Lord Bhattacharyya said, are counted as UK incomes.

The income of the noble Lord, Lord Browne of Madingley, could be attributed to any of the 35 countries in which he operates, but because it is attributed to the UK, UK income statistics show that our income inequality is very large. I think that the noble Lord perfectly well deserves his £30 million if he makes £15 billion or so of profits—I do not begrudge him that in any way whatever—but the important thing that I want to explain is that the concentration of financial markets here, the welcome environment that the UK offers multinationals to locate here, and the very great activity of mergers, acquisitions and hedge funds here mean that, at the top of the 1 per cent or less of income distribution, people have opportunities to make enormous gains from capital market operations.

Does that have serious welfare consequences? I agree with my noble friend Lord Giddens that it does not. One may not like to live in a society of great inequality, but I do not think that we still live in a society of haves and have nots. We have the haves, the have mores and the have much, much more than anyone elses. It is exciting that the UK has this financial capability, but if we wanted to kill it, it would be very easy to do so. One thing that governments are very good at doing is killing industry, but I hope that we do not do that.

My Lords, I too welcome the debate. I will concentrate more on the domestic than the global implications, and I shall put my cards on the table straightaway; I come from a political tradition that says that equality of outcome is as important as equality of opportunity. I am not quite sure where the Government stand on that.

As my noble friend Lord Lea of Crondall has said, when he and I were taught economics, the UK was one of the most equal societies in Europe; at the end of the 1980s, we were one of the least equal. It is true that there have been several welcome measures under this Government, such as a concentration on the least well-off, the minimum wage and the tax credit system, that have been designed, in part, to reverse that. But the net effect of all that effort and substantial public expenditure is that we have just about halted the shift to inequality in income, but only just about held the position that we occupied at the end of the Thatcher era. Indeed, given the very top incomes, as my noble friend Lord Lea of Crondall has said, it is not even that. So far as wealth is concerned, inequality has increased. That applies as much to post-tax income as it does to pre-tax income, and I am certainly not arguing that all this can be rectified by substantial redistributive taxation, although I think that we could with a little more of that.

My first question to the Minister is: why is this happening? Is it because, as the title of the debate might imply, globalisation inevitably causes greater inequality in developed economies as we struggle to compete with India and China and so on, or is it because greater equality of outcome is indeed no longer an objective of public policy? Is it just that the Government's interventions to which I referred simply take a long time to permeate the system? Or is it, as my noble friend Lord Lea suggested, that British business and the British labour market behave differently from certain other economies? After all, other European economies are also subject to pressures from globalisation. I know that some people would argue that they have not coped with it as efficiently as the UK has. Yet, as the noble Lord, Lord Bhattacharyya, has pointed out, Germany is an infinitely better exporting nation than us and the Nordic countries have higher achievements in competitive indices than we have ever achieved.

It is true that calculations of the distribution of income are just snapshots at any given time. There are those who would argue that it is not the snapshot but the question of social mobility that matters and those who used to argue that, although the United States was a clearly unequal society, mobility applied; therefore, inequality at any given time was not relevant. Unfortunately, that is no longer true of the United States: it never was true of the black or Hispanic populations, or other minorities, and it is true of an increasingly smaller proportion in the United States. Indeed, the US is not only more unequal in a snapshot sense than most of Europe; it is also one of the least socially mobile western economies. But if the United States is at the bottom of that league, the United Kingdom is close to the bottom.

Why have social mobility and inequality not improved since the end of the Thatcher era, which I think most of us now recognise as a very regressive era in British public policy? Some of that is no doubt due to international pressures, but there are at least three areas of domestic policy that make a difference, particularly to the social mobility argument. I have had cause to underline in housing debates the degree of stratification in the housing market, which has led to ghettoisation and the prevention of people moving socially in that area.

Education is a topical issue, but I do not think that either the proponents or opponents of the recent White Paper have given us a way to ensure that the education system stops failing working class children. Intervention in the labour market and the minimum wage have been important, but the enforcement of minimum labour standards in other continental European countries is better and more effective than in this country.

There are many versions of the European social model, but Europe has certainly delivered greater equality than either the United States or Britain. There are some lessons to be learnt, but we should also recognise that globalisation does not inevitably lead to inequality in our economy—trade is based on comparative advantage, not absolute advantage. Therefore, there is no point in us trying to emulate Chinese labourers' wages or boardroom salaries in Texas.

All those policies are relevant. I end by asking whether it is at least possible to adopt one procedural measure: to check on each new area of government policy, as we do for gender—rightly so, in view of the report today—or race, and sometimes for region. Is the impact of that policy likely to increase or decrease inequality of wealth and income in our country?

My Lords, the noble Lord, Lord Lea, has raised an important issue, which is something of a challenge to deal with in a five-minute speech. As a number of noble Lords have said, the starting point is income in aggregate: distribution of income has not shifted significantly, certainly over the past decade and during the lifetime of this Government. Over a number of decades, there has been a big shift in the relative importance of various sectors of the UK economy, which has had a significant effect on individuals.

Noble Lords have talked already about the strain which our manufacturing industry has been under. Compared with manufacturers in the rest of Europe, we have done very badly in taking up opportunities presented by the growing economies, particularly in China and India. Over the past decade, German exports have increased by about 60 per cent and ours have not increased at all. Interestingly, our exports of services over the same period to those countries have increased strongly and it is in that area that we have a comparative advantage, although I agree with the noble Lord, Lord Bhattacharyya, that we should not, as it were, cast manufacturing aside and say that we cannot do it. We are very good in some sectors and we need to look carefully at how to strengthen them.

However, there is no doubt that globalisation offers more easy opportunities for Britain in the field of services. I declare an interest as a director of a brand design consultancy called Elmwood, which is based in Leeds and employs 50 staff. Recently we opened an office in Melbourne, where we are doing great work using a combination of locally recruited, British and Canadian staff. The company has a comparative advantage in some aspects of the design world and it is going to grow in no small measure internationally. Having operated in Australia and having been working in the United States, we are now looking to operate in the middle—looking at Asia on the way to Australia. So there are huge opportunities in the service sector that will continue to deliver significant benefits.

One aspect of globalisation that has not been mentioned this evening is the effect of the increasingly free market in labour, particularly within the enlarged European Union. This is having a significant impact on the UK labour market. Just as I would argue with the noble Lord, Lord Bhattacharyya, and others that globalisation and the growth it brings has been beneficial, the effect of the growing numbers of Polish plumbers or Polish dentists and other ancillary workers in the health service coming into the UK economy has been beneficial. They have filled gaps in the market which we were unable easily to meet ourselves. Indeed, one of the huge successes of this Government is that, by introducing the minimum wage, the inflow of potentially very cheap labour has not resulted in very low wages, particularly in the public sector where many of these people are working.

I agree with the noble Lord, Lord Desai, about the importance and significance of the financial services sector in the City in pushing up both wealth and income at the top end. But, as with footballers where we are also global leaders, that has resulted in inevitably high levels of income. Is that acceptable? At one level I suspect that not much can be done about it, but equally we all feel slightly queasy at the thought of footballers earning £100,000 a week or people in the business world earning many millions in a short period. A number of noble Lords have suggested how to moderate the growing inequalities of wealth—if one shares the views of the right reverend Prelate, this is not how we want mankind and humanity to develop in the longer term. Trying to develop a philanthropic culture is important and the Government can take a lead in this. They may have their work cut out for them with some of the people we have mentioned, but it is a good start.

Another approach is redistributive taxation. I agree with the noble Lord, Lord Giddens, on the principle. My party has argued that a higher top rate of tax would be beneficial. It has the advantage that we might collect quite a large proportion of it. The noble Lord's preferred measure would be to introduce higher levels of inheritance tax. However, it has a major demerit in that the wealthier you are, the easier it seems to be to circumvent it. I am not sure it works. However, I agree with most noble Lords that looking at how to moderate excess at the top through a combination of moral persuasion and redistributive tax policy is something to which this House should return.

My Lords, I thank the noble Lord, Lord Lea of Crondall, for securing this debate, and noble Lords on all sides of the House, for their interesting contributions. The noble Lord, Lord Lea, asked me to comment on the young Etonians. As an old Etonian, rather than a young one, I would not be impertinent enough to enter that frame.

Impressive as all the arguments have been, I think it is worthwhile examining the question itself. It is a matter of both economic and social concern that there are still people living in poverty in the United Kingdom, as there are in many other countries of the world, especially those to which the noble Lord, Lord Lea, referred. No one seeks massive inequalities in the distribution of wealth. It is tempting to suppose that the crux of the issue lies in the distribution of wealth, but surely there is a greater virtue in improving the prosperity and well-being of the less-well-off members of society, rather than worrying about relative wealth. It is much more important for the poor to become better off than to achieve equality by making the rich poorer. That process has been proved to reduce the prosperity of all, in spite of what the noble Lord, Lord Giddens, has said. Surely the criterion on which globalisation should be judged is whether it has raised the general standards of wealth and prosperity for the greatest number of people and whether it has contributed to an improved life for the poorer members of society.

Globalisation has come about from the removal of trade barriers and tariffs. Their progressive removal, often against much opposition, has encouraged international trade, which in recent years has been accelerated by the development of technology. Trade barriers were created to protect vested interests from outside competition which would force prices lower and create pressure to improve quality. With no outside competition, prices could be maintained at artificially high levels and there was no impetus to produce better quality goods. The effect of those higher prices was to restrict the availability of the protected goods and services to the better off. The poor could not afford, or would find it difficult, to pay higher prices. It is very much to its shame that the European Union persists in the practice of trade barriers, notably in agriculture. If it were not for the historic protection of European farmers against the forces of competition from elsewhere in the world, the price of food could tumble by as much as 50 per cent. It is an example of how restrictive trade practices work to keep prices up.

Where trade has not been obstructed, the less well off have benefited. With the reduction in tariffs and trade barriers came globalisation, but with globalisation there was a massive increase in the availability of cheaper and higher-quality goods, as well as the arrival in this country of international corporations, as pointed out by the noble Lord, Lord Bhattacharyya. To see how consumers benefit, your Lordships need only think of the impact on all our lives: mobile telephones, shoes, clothes, cars, cameras, televisions—an endless succession of goods. The same competition will help to reduce costs in service industries.

It is impossible to tell precisely and objectively whether the abolition of trade barriers and the resulting globalisation has, in the short term, created greater inequality of income and wealth in the United Kingdom. It has certainly made a massive contribution to the improvement in the well-being of the less well off, who can afford things their parents and grandparents could only have dreamt of.

Globalisation, in spite of its faults, has been a force for good. Far from reversing the long-term trend towards equality, globalisation has been one of its driving forces and it would have been prevented or reduced by maintaining trade barriers. Where trade barriers have been maintained, it is the poor who pay the price, from farmers in Africa to Mr Mandelson's proposed tariff on leather shoes, which will restrict their availability to those on tight budgets.

The contributions to the debate have been impressive. I doubt whether there is much division over our objectives. We all want a more prosperous world. We all want an increasing number of people to enjoy the affluence that most take for granted.

My Lords, I start by thanking all noble Lords who have contributed to today's debate. It is a matter we could have discussed all week and still have had things left to say. I would particularly like to thank my noble friend Lord Lea for tabling the Question. The House will readily recognise that for him these matters are not just of passing academic interest, and that he has given distinguished service in the cause of greater equality over many years. It has been a wide-ranging debate; we have covered cricket, football and bank robberies, as well as more fundamental economic matters.

There is no standard definition of globalisation. Typically the term is used to describe the increasing integration of world markets. Technological progress and the rise of emerging markets have driven increasing international flows of goods and services, including finance, to which my noble friend Lord Desai made reference; people and resources; and ideas and culture. Most commentators judge that the present wave of globalisation started in the late 1980s. Globalisation and technological progress are the key drivers to rising prosperity in the UK, the EU and the rest of the world. Over the last 50 years world trade, which the noble Lord, Lord Howard, spoke about, has expanded some 75 times.

Globalisation has the potential to generate substantial economic benefits. Production and resources can be allocated around the world in the most efficient manner. Technology can also be distributed more widely, increasing the productivity of the world's workers. My noble friend Lord Bhattacharyya spoke with great conviction and expertise on this matter. Developing countries are also now playing an increasing role, and accounted for 29 per cent of world trade in 2001. Indeed, one of the key successes of the UK's recent presidency of the G7 was to convince the other economic powers to commit to further trade liberalisation so that developing countries can grow faster. Emerging economies account for an increasing share of global output, trade and investment.

The Government are committed to promoting further economic openness, and to an ambitious pro-development conclusion to the current Doha development agenda round of trade talks by the end of this year. If all merchandise and agricultural trade were freed, the world economy would be boosted by nearly $300 billion per year by 2015—more, if trade in services were also liberalised. Properly managed—as the right reverend Prelate reminded us, it is not just a question of letting the tide come in—globalisation will also help the Government to achieve their economic targets of improving the UK's productivity, and thus people's welfare and prosperity. It will encourage UK firms to concentrate on those sectors of the economy where we have an advantage over our international competitors. It will give firms access to new technology and reward them for their innovations.

Globalisation will also provide consumers with a greater choice of goods and services at lower prices. Around the world, those countries most open to the global economy are growing the fastest. We also need further globalisation to help developing countries and provide them with access to rich countries' markets. In agriculture alone, barriers prevent developing countries earning up to $75 billion a year, significantly more than current aid flows. That is why the G7 under the UK presidency agreed to work to further liberalise world trade.

Lower trade barriers to poor countries is a necessity, but not a sufficient condition for those countries to reach their potential. Problems of capacity also need to be addressed, such as trade-related infrastructures like roads, ports and customs, and, more importantly, the basic systems that help to keep populations healthy and well skilled. To help countries invest in capacity, the Government have increased aid flows, and UK aid will reach nearly £6.5 billion a year by 2007-08. In 2005, under the UK presidencies of the EU and the G8, the international community has committed to raise an additional $50 billion of aid by 2010, and to cancel 100 per cent of the multinational debts of the world's poorest countries.

Even though globalisation has the potential to benefit everyone, there have been increasing concerns, some expressed tonight, about its impact. People fear the changes globalisation will cause, even though these changes are rational and probably inevitable in the long run. As this debate shows, there are worries that while globalisation might generally promote faster economic growth, this may be at the expense of greater inequality. Inequality in the UK has risen since the 1970s. During the 1980s the income gap between high and low earners grew significantly. The gap stabilised in the 1990s and has since shown no firm upward or downward trend. Several noble Lords referred to that, including the noble Lord, Lord Newby, the noble Lord, Lord Lea of Crondall, himself, and the noble Lord, Lord Whitty. Some academics have recently found tentative evidence that the income of the poorest people has started to recover slightly, relative to top earners. However, the gap between top earners and those in the middle of the distribution has continued to widen. The relatively better performance of the low paid could possibly be due to such measures as tax credit, referred to by a number of speakers today.

I would like to deal with the issue raised, in particular by the noble Lord, Lord Lea of Crondall, about the pay and pensions of top directors. My noble friend Lord Giddens also posed questions about this. It is crucial that our top businesses have top managers if they are going to perform internationally and if our economy is to grow. For companies to attract, retain and motivate people of the right calibre and experience, they have to pay the going international rate. However, it is important that directors are held to account for their actions and that their pay reflects their performance. World-class pay should demand world-class performance. Ultimately, it is for the companies' owners—the shareholders—to judge whether this is the case. It is not for the Government to determine or dictate directors' levels of pay.

However, the Government do have a role in ensuring that a framework is in place that allows shareholders to exercise their influence effectively on companies' remuneration policies. That is why the Government introduced the Directors' Remuneration Report Regulations 2002 to improve transparency and make directors more accountable to shareholders, and why we are working with the Financial Reporting Council in implementing the Combined Code on Corporate Governance. These are matters I know we will debate further during the passage of the Company Law Reform Bill. Recent data shows that this approach is having some impact in moderating pay at the top and certainly making it more closely related to performance.

Wealth inequality has also continued to widen and is greater than income inequality. We would expect the distribution of wealth to be more unequal than that of income, because a large part of wealth inequality is due to the accumulation of houses and other assets as people age. As such, much of the wealth gap is between young and old people, not rich and poor. Economists, however, are unsure of the role globalisation has played in the widening of inequality. My noble friend Lord Giddens challenged this mantra. Much of the rise in equality is due to workers with the skills and education wanted by today's economy receiving much higher wages. Although the income of workers without the new skills is still rising, some groups have fallen behind over the last 25 years. The academic consensus seems to be that the growth in this skills premium is mostly due to technological progress. Workers today need to know how to use the new technology, particularly the new information technology. There is little evidence linking globalisation, specifically, to rising inequality. It is also interesting to note that while many people seek to stop globalisation because of fears about inequality, few have sought to slow the development of new technologies, which seem to play more of a role in widening the income gap.

While this Government are committed to globalisation, we also recognise that it can create challenges for some groups. Even as the economy expands and exploits the opportunities unlocked through greater trade, some businesses will find it difficult to deal with increased international competition. Businesses in the low-skill sectors will find the competition particularly intense. This inevitably means that some workers will leave present jobs and will need to find work elsewhere. They may find that they need new skills to compete. Without proper economic management globalisation could lead to greater inequality but that does not mean that we should attempt to turn back globalisation and protect our businesses from the rest of the world. Experience in this and other countries has shown that protectionist policies are costly and ultimately ineffective. Restricting access to our country's markets would also go against the commitments this country has made to the developing countries.

The right reverend Prelate the Bishop of Worcester said that humankind should take control of this process. I agree. The approach the Government have adopted is to increase flexibility in the economy so that business and workers can respond to new opportunities and shift the expanding areas of our economy. It is critical to ensure that flexibility is accompanied by fairness through polices which support individuals through periods of change. The New Deal in particular has helped over 3 million people find work. In parallel with changes to free up the economy, social policies have been introduced that provide support without blocking change. The tax credit is one example. As a result of personal tax and benefit measures introduced since 1997, from April 2006 families with children will on average be £1,500 a year better off and families with children in the poorest fifth of the population will be on average £3,350 a year better off. To spread wealth more widely the Government seek to make saving, assets and wealth ownership accessible to all and so give opportunity to the many, not the few.

My noble friend Lord Whitty posed a question about procedural matters. He asked whether the Government had to assess the impact on inequality of new initiatives that came forward. That is an interesting proposition. In some respects it would be very easy to measure the impact on inequality of a measure such as a tax change, a tax credit or a pension credit change. The impact of investment in education, science and skills is less easy to spot immediately. That is a dynamic process. However, it is an interesting thought that is worth developing.

In the longer term we need to ensure that this country has the skills needed to successfully compete on the international stage. To ensure our skills base the Government have invested in education and will continue to do so. Over the past 10 years the proportion of graduates in the labour force has grown from 19 per cent to 26 per cent. Since 1994 the number of people with no qualifications has fallen from 21 per cent to 14 per cent.

If measures are taken to increase the country's flexibility to adjust to change, including investment in infrastructure and better regulation, and by investing in our skills, innovation and science base, globalisation can drive growth in this country, as it is around the world, without eroding the progress this Government have made on reducing poverty and tackling inequality.

publicwhip.minor-heading: Natural Environment and Rural Communities Bill

speech.p: House again in Committee.
Clause 57 [Members of National Park authorities]:
moved Amendment No. 307:
Page 22, line 28, leave out subsection (2) and insert—
"( ) In paragaph 1, for sub-paragraphs (2) to (6) (constitution of National Park authorities) substitute—
"(2) A National Park authority shall consist of an appropriate balance of national and local members, consisting of—
(a) a specified number of directly elected members who live or work within the National Park boundary; and
(b) a specified number of other members to be appointed by the Secretary of State;
and "specified" means specified in the relevant order.
(3) The total number of elected members must exceed the number of other members having regard to the minimum proportions for the Secretary of State's appointees as described in subsection (4) below.
(4) The total number of members who are appointed by the Secretary of State shall—
(a) as respects any National Park authority for a National Park in England, be a minimum proportion of 25 per cent;
(b) as respects any National Park authority for a National Park in Wales, be a minimum proportion of 25 per cent.

(5) The Secretary of State shall consult all relevant authorities and interested bodies in specifying the number of local authority members, parish members and other members to be appointed by him in the relevant order.""

The main difference between the present system and that which this amendment proposes is that the proportion of national park authority members who do not represent the national interest shall be directly elected. I reiterate my interest as a vice-president of the Council for National Parks. This is not the view of that body.

However, we on the Liberal Democrat Benches believe that, given the increased social and economic duties of national park authorities and the fact that they now have full planning duties, the national interest should constitute no less than 25 per cent of the membership of the national park authority—that would safeguard all the national interests—and that the people best able to represent the social, economic and environmental interests of the park as a whole are those people who live and work within the park.

In the same way as one would expect members of any other local authority to either live or work within the area they represent, we believe that this should equally apply to those representing a national park. At the moment, a national park member may live 40 or 50 miles or more from the park, even though they are an indirectly elected member. While many may absolutely have the parks' best interest at heart and may do their best at representing it, there is no doubt that it makes a difference if you do not live or work within the park. We expect people to be representative of their local authority because they understand how that community works—they understand its wishes and desires. How are national park members different from local authority members? It is true that you could end up with the parish council members from within the park, but those who are from the principal authorities—the district and county councils—could live outside the park. Then, there are the national members as well, so you could end up with a situation where very few people either lived or worked within the park but could still be on the national park authority. As the Government take forward the legislation, this is an appropriate moment to look again at the issue. I beg to move.

I wonder whether I am the only Member of the Committee speaking in the debate who is not on one local national park body or another. I have no such interest to declare although my home is in a national park, in the Lake District.

What is it that we expect of the Members of the national parks authorities? What contribution do they bring, or ought they to bring, to the work of national parks? It is right that we should be seeking a wider mix of membership. That was supported by the various reviews that have taken place, both in England and in Wales, where wider membership was supported and indeed the consultation process suggested precisely that.

However, we have a departure from an important principle in the way in which the Bill is now drafted, in Clause 57. The Bill will give a future Minister or Secretary of State enormous discretion to change the numbers of persons in membership of a national park authority. That means that the Minister or Secretary of State will have enormous powers to change the membership and balance it in one way or another. I would have thought that that is not desirable. I understand that the department will say, "We need flexibility to deal with future contingencies". That is fair enough; one does not want to tie the department or the Government in such a way that any slight change in circumstances will require new primary legislation. However, Amendment No. 307A gives the Minister the necessary discretion while at the same time ensuring that there is a proper mix.

Why is the mix important? It is important because national parks are not just local bodies serving people in the local area. National parks are, by their very name, national bodies which provide a service and provide facilities for people from all over the country. That is why so many people travel to the national parks for their leisure and recreation. It would be rather limiting to say that we do not need national members but should simply appoint people on a very local basis. I am not saying that the Government have that in mind but my concern is that the very wide discretion that the Government are taking upon themselves in Clause 57 may well work against having the sort of membership mix that is conducive to the effective running of national parks.

I apologise to the Committee because I did not hear the opening remarks of the noble Baroness, but I did come in at the tail end of her speech. I am bound to say that on balance I prefer the amendment of the noble Lords, Lord Dubs and Lord Judd, to that of the noble Baroness, merely because I am not sure what the noble Baroness means by,
"a specified number of directly elected members who live or work within the National Park boundary".
Does she mean directly elected members of parish councils, district councils or county councils? Or does she actually mean that there should be elections to the park authority?
Just to clear that up, I mean directly elected to the park authority, like to any other authority.

That slightly changes my perspective. The idea of having directly elected members to the park authority is very interesting. It considerably alters the concept of local democracy, particularly in view of the fact that there would be an immense potential for conflict between the elected members of the park authority and elected members of the parishes and county councils within it and around it. However, that is nothing new because there is inevitably in life already conflict between members of county councils, members of district councils, and members of parish councils. From time to time there are wonderful occasions when they all reach agreement; that is the nature of democracy. If we are talking about directly elected members of park authorities, that would be a considerable change in the way that this works, and it would give the parks authorities considerably more direct interest in their communities. It would represent a considerable strengthening of the democratic process for national parks. If that is what we are talking about, it is almost a revolution. It is a real and major change. I have always been a big believer in democracy. I find that proposal quite attractive and of considerable interest. I wait with interest to hear the Minister's reaction.

It always upsets me when I find myself not in total agreement with the noble Baroness, Lady Miller. Wherever we sit in this House, we have the utmost regard for her dedication and commitment to the issues that we discussing. Frankly, I am bemused by part of her proposal. Naturally, I am delighted that she is in line with part of the amendment put down in my name and that of my noble friend Lord Dubs, but I am a bit bemused by the rest of her proposal. I always looked at the Liberal Party as one that regards itself as the praetorian guard for the principle of local government and local democracy. It seems to me therefore that the best way in which the views of the local community can be represented in the administration of the parks is to see the local authorities—whether local councils, parish councils or district councils—represented in the way that is now provided for. I do not quite see what this new embellishment on democracy would achieve that is qualitatively better than concentrating on that.

I warmly support my noble friend Lord Dubs in his objectivity as someone who does not carry any responsibility in a park body; official or unofficial. It is incumbent on us all to remember that the parks are national parks, as my noble friend emphasised. They are there for the recreation and regeneration of the people of England and Wales as a whole. As the pressures and stresses of society increase, they become more important as a resource of this kind. It is therefore tremendously important to ensure that, in their administration, the interests of those from the rest of the nation who enjoy them are well represented and ensured. I am worried about the Government's proposal. If one took an extreme example of how the cookie might crumble, it is not impossible that you could have a local authority element of 95 per cent, and that would leave precious little room for those who were supposed to represent the general public as a whole by being the national members.

I have already paid enough compliments to the Minister this evening. He knows how much I admire him and how much I am behind this Bill, whatever my sense of bereavement and grief at having been denied the opportunity to support him on specific legislation this evening. I would like just to make this suggestion to him. I am sure he will agree on reflection that what is now being proposed by the Government was not a matter for consultation in the context of the recent reviews of the English and Welsh national park authorities. That means that the reservations and hopes expressed today become all the more important because they represent a very considerable body of opinion in the country. While I would not therefore necessarily look to my noble friend to concede the point tonight, I hope that he will, with his usual goodwill, give a real undertaking to the Committee that he will take away this point about a 25 per cent guaranteed national membership, think about it carefully, and bring back some constructive proposals of his own on Report.

I rise briefly to comment on one or two matters. We on these Benches are also concerned about the wide discretion that this government amendment proposes. We recognise and accept the point made by the noble Lord, Lord Judd, that they are national parks. However, I think that having a 25 per cent proportion seems to be commonly agreed and is the right one to aim at. If the amendment requires directly elected members to the authority, I have to ask the noble Baroness, Lady Miller, who will be in that election process? Is it everybody who lives in the area, or is it down to the parish councils, or the district councils or the county councils which fall into that particular area? Secondly, if we are going to have more national parks—and obviously the case of South Downs is still outstanding—that covers a great number of local authorities. How will they decide who will or will not be elected?
When the issue was debated in another place, Jim Knight, the Minister, said:
"We are considering the mix of members, not the number of them, which will be set in secondary legislation".—[Official Report, Commons Standing Committee A, 30/6/05; col. 239.]

We have a chance here in primary legislation to get it right. I should be grateful if the Minister would clarify that, because I am somewhat alarmed if it is to be left to secondary legislation when there is a chance to set it in primary legislation.

I apologise to the noble Lord, Lord Dubs, for not being in the Chamber when he moved his amendment. I have read it with interest and I would be curious to know why he thinks that it is appropriate for the Secretary of State to be responsible for appointing parish members. I ought to know the current legislation, but I cannot remember whether parish councillors are appointed by the Secretary of State. I do not think they are. To the best of my knowledge, I think a nominee is appointed by the parish council, which seems to me the correct way of doing it. One thing is absolutely certain. Since parish councillors were introduced on to national park committees, it has made a great deal of difference and brought a much greater local democratic process into the system. But I am curious to know why the noble Lord thought it was appropriate for the Secretary of State to appoint the parish councillors, rather than for them to appoint themselves.

The Minister can probably explain the previous legislation better than I can, but my understanding of the Environment Act 1995 is that the agency shall consist of not fewer than eight or more than 15 members, of whom three shall be appointed by the Minister and the others by the Secretary of State. I am not aware that the previous legislation was so specific as regards parish councils; I do not think that they were mentioned. The Minister might prefer to answer that point rather than leaving it to me.

I come from Somerset where we have one national park, shared with Devon, and a number of areas of outstanding natural beauty. The interests of the residents of national parks are more important than those of visitors to national parks; after all, most of the residents live there all 12 months of the year and, if they were not there, there would be far less of interest, beauty and accessibility for the visitors to benefit from. I would like the balance tilted somewhat in favour of the residents. Perhaps I should mention that national parks came into being as a result of a report from a commission chaired by Sir Arthur Hobhouse, who was a neighbour and friend of my father.

Maybe one way out of the dilemma—it was hinted at by the noble Lord, Lord Judd, who wanted a further period of reflection—is that there should be at least a convention. Perhaps it should be referred to or incorporated in some way in the legislation, but its practical effect should be that the Secretary of State would only or at least usually appoint elected councillors—and especially the parish councillors to which the noble Earl, Lord Peel, referred—from the area of the park in question, not from the rest of the county or district so that those councillors are not actually resident or representing the people in question. I offer that as a conceivable way out of the difficulty.

I should correct what I said; I am not sure that I got it right when I answered the noble Earl's question about parish councils. I ought to withdraw what I said and leave it to the Minister to put the Committee right.
On that issue, the advice that I have received is that it is always the Secretary of State who appoints the nominees from the parish councils; he or she will do that in all cases.

The two amendments are on an interesting subject. I garner three general principles raised by them, and I shall address them before I make some comments on the practicability of Amendment No. 307 itself. The first general principle, which is raised by both amendments, is that the primary legislation should specify that national members should always make up at least 25 per cent of an authority. The second general principle, again raised by both amendments, is that before laying an order to establish the membership of an authority the Government should consult not just the local authorities affected but,
"all relevant authorities and interested bodies".

The third general principle, which is raised only by Amendment No. 307, tabled by the noble Baroness, Lady Miller, is that national park authorities should include some members—perhaps a majority—who are directly elected to that authority.

Let me take those three principles in turn. First, I refer to the 25 per cent rule. That is the case for specifying in primary legislation that 25 per cent of each national park authority must always be made up of those other members whom the Secretary of State appoints, and who are often referred to as the national members to distinguish them from their colleagues who are drawn from local authorities or parish councils. The key consideration is not so much the 25 per cent figure itself, which is in any case consistent with current practice, but whether it is sensible for any level to be set in primary legislation, and whether that is a decision best left for secondary legislation, when the make-up of each individual national park authority—one is different from another—is being set by statutory instrument.

The Government's clear view is that such decisions are best left to secondary legislation where they can be taken on a case-by-case basis, and can reflect the context in which NPAs are working at the time. The Welsh Assembly Government are preparing to consult on membership arrangements and have expressed the view that they would not want the Bill to pre-empt the decisions that they will take in light of their consultation.

The second principle is whether the Government should have to consult more widely before introducing secondary legislation. Although the existing statutory requirement is to consult only the local authorities, it is already Defra's practice to include other consultees who may have an interest. In practice we are already doing what the amendment seeks. Perhaps it could be argued that no change to the legislation is therefore needed.

I turn to the principle of directly elected members, which is again part of Amendment No. 307 but not Amendment No.307A. This is a well worn issue, having recently been debated and rejected in another place. Directly elected members for England and Welsh park authorities was a subject discussed when the existing legislation was being enacted, and was looked at again in both the English and Welsh reviews. The issue has never commanded general support. Indeed, as the noble Baroness was frank enough to say at the start of her speech, neither the Association of National Park Authorities nor the Council for National Parks supports the idea.

National park authorities are unique bodies. We need to recognise that and devise our approach accordingly. They have many of the characteristics of local authorities, including being subject to most of the generic local government legislation. They also have some features of a non-departmental public body. That duality reflects their dual responsibilities. They serve the country as a whole—they are after all national assets and called national parks—but they also have a direct responsibility towards those whose lives are spent in the park. The noble Lord talked about them in his speech.

The current arrangements reflect their unique role rather well. At present, each authority has some members who have been elected to local authorities in the area, some members who have been recruited through a national competition, and in England some members who have been elected to parish councils. That mix gives them a broad range of skills and expertise that they perhaps need. It also ensures that they do not overlook either their national or local responsibilities. Is it na-ve to say that the real test of the current system is whether or not it actually works? It seems to us that it does. It certainly seemed to work to the authors of the 2002 Defra review of English national park authorities, who said that they were not persuaded that directly elected members would bring clear benefits. The separate review of the Welsh national park authorities also found no consensus on this issue. I have already mentioned what the Welsh Assembly Government plan in terms of consultation. In short, and to end, we see no need for a directly elected component. We believe that to introduce one could unbalance the approach that has proved successful for many years since independent national park authorities were established.

Moving on from general principles, there are some drafting weaknesses in Amendment No. 307, which we fear is ambiguous and would not be workable. First, it is unclear whether it is intended for local authority and parish members to remain on national park authorities. The start of the amendment implies that they do not, yet they are mentioned in subsection (5). While the amendment would remove the part of the Bill which specifies that there are to be three categories of members—local authority, parish and national—perhaps inconsistency leaves in place those parts of the existing legislation which relate to each category.

Secondly, Amendment No. 307 does not define what working in a national park would mean. Would part-time or unpaid work qualify? Would a directly elected member lose his or her place on the authority if they lost their job? Thirdly, the amendment does not specify how direct collections would be run; I refer, for example—and this point has already been made by the noble Baroness—to the simple question of who would be eligible to vote. For those reasons, I am afraid that we cannot support either of the amendments tonight.

I thank the Minister for his reply, which he will not be surprised to discover I find slightly disappointing. I am sure that he would agree that, back before women were given the vote, whether they should do so was probably called a "well worn issue" when it was debated time and again. Some issues of democracy are just that.

The hour of the night makes me interrupt the noble Baroness. I am interested in her comparison with the right of women to vote—particularly as my great aunt was Mrs Pankhurst, so I am not sure that I relish the comparison.

That is probably—in fact, definitely—one to the Minister. But the noble Lord, Lord Hylton, made the point that the views of residents of the park are important. The duality the Minister mentioned is absolutely recognised in my amendment by the 25 per cent proportion that shall be national members.

Given the wide-ranging remit of national park authority business—which includes planning, consideration of where residents will have their homes in future, what sort of business will be allowed and so on—I must ask Members who spoke against this proposition why that is any different from members of any other local authority. Is it right that people who live 50 miles away are making fundamental decisions for those residents? That is what the indirectly elected members of county councils who live well outside the park boundaries are—my husband was one of them when he chaired Exmoor National Park. I speak with no disrespect for what he, or anyone else outside parks who represented national park authorities, did, but the fact is that those who live and work in the park authority are best placed. On the argument about how you would qualify, those rules about whether you live or work there, and what happens if you lose you job and so on, are all well laid down in local authority elections legislation.

The noble Lord, Lord Judd, says that he is bemused. I know that he is never disingenuous, so I could not possibly accuse him of that. Nevertheless, this argument will be discussed again. It is right that residents should have a say. I was not aware that the first Scottish park has locally elected members elected by a specified park, but I am interested to hear that and will look into it further before report stage. In the mean time, I beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

Perhaps I may just entreat my noble friend not to be quite as absolute as he sounded in his rejection of these amendments, and to go away and ponder some of the merit which they represent. In my view it would be good if he could come back with a constructive proposal on Report to meet some of the anxieties.

I put it to my noble friend that what my noble friend Lord Dubs and I suggest in our amendment is a win-win situation because it retains flexibility for the future, which we are the first to agree is vital, but it also protects the national interests of national park authorities. I put it to my noble friend that there is not really room for complacency on this. It is not true to suggest that there is never a tension between the national interest and local interests. It is therefore, it seems to me, very important that, because of the national character of the parks, national representation is a guaranteed element within whatever equation is reached.

My noble friend referred, I think, to the recent review of the Welsh national parks and the English national parks. It is interesting that the review of the Welsh national parks made no recommendation to change the mix of two-thirds local and one-third national, while the English review recommended more of a swing towards increasing national membership, with three-fifths local and two-fifths national appointees. It is presently of course a quarter for the latter. I hope that my noble friend, with his usual consideration, will feel able to go away and think more about this and perhaps come back to us with a more positive response at Report stage.
Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.
[Amendment No. 307A not moved.]
Clause 57 agreed to.
Clause 58 [Expenditure by National Parks authorities]:
On Question, Whether Clause 58 stand part of the Bill?

Apparently, the definition of "significant" is still a problem so far as we are concerned. It was not placed in the 1949 Act and has been causing difficulties within the national parks. For the past seven years I have been trying to persuade the Government to define "significant" wherever it occurs in a Bill. I have already had a go on this in a series of sittings on the Commons Bill.

The fact that the task of definition is not easy should not necessarily mean that it is not included. The effect of Clause 58 is to completely take off the brakes. On page 42 there is an interesting subsection which reads,
"any increase attributable to this Act in the sums payable by virtue of any other Act out of money so provided".
It relates to the statement on the previous page:
"There is to be paid out of money provided by Parliament".

Can the Minister reassure me that we will never face the possibility of a national park overspend as a result of Clause 58 and have to be bailed out by government under the provisions of Clause 98(b)? I beg to move.
